description: Possibly a blend of blob +â€Ž gob or a clipping of globule. An element of sound symbolism is clearly involved: compare such phonetically and semantically similar words as glop, gop, blob, clump and clod. (Still, globe, clump and clod may be related via the Proto-Indo-European root *gel-; compare clew.)
In the programming sense, originates from the early (c. 1970) Unix command glob; short for global.
In the biological sense, proposed by Bevil R. Conway and Doris Y. Tsao, by analogy with the cytochrome-oxidase "blobs" of V1, an earlier stage in the hierarchical elaboration of colour.

entries.meaning: A round, shapeless or amorphous lump, as of a semisolid substance.
examples: He put a glob of paint into the cup and went on painting.

entries.meaning: (programming) A limited pattern matching technique using wildcards, less powerful than a regular expression.
(biology) A millimeter-sized colour module found beyond the visual area V2 in the brain's parvocellular pathway.

verbs.description: glob (third-person singular simple present globs, present participle globbing, simple past and past participle globbed)

entries.meaning: To stick in globs or lumps.
examples: Paint was globbing off the wall.

entries.meaning: (programming) To carry out pattern matching using a glob.
